ImageContent.Description: Where cobbled charm meets coastal cool, Gdańsk is a dynamic city in Poland's Pomorskie province. It is part of Tricity—a metropolitan area along the Gdańsk Bay that includes the neighbouring coastal cities of Sopot and Gdynia, along with nearby towns. The city likely takes its name from 'Gdania,' an earlier name for the Motława river that runs through it.
ImageContent.Headline: Pastel dreams and still waters
ImageContent.Title: Gdańsk on the banks of the Motława river, Poland

ImageContent.Description: They fly backward, dive-bomb rivals and travel farther than most road trippers. Meet the rufous hummingbird—photographed in Golden Gate Park in San Francisco, California, United States. The bird, one of nine species in the genus Selasphorus, gets its name from its rusty, reddish-orange feathers. Males flash copper backs and red throat patches that shimmer in the sun. Females are more subdued but still carry streaks of rufous on their sides and tails.
ImageContent.Headline: A hum-dinger of a day
ImageContent.Title: Rufous hummingbird, Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, California, United States

MapLink.Url: //platform.bing.com/geo/REST/v1/Imagery/Map/RoadVibrant/37.771893,-122.454659/5?key=AsSOKo7OOz5VAtfAj0rjgaXlhCrCZI6PGbLj7GCH8IW2HUalyg4BVhqA0z77PRCj&c=en-CA&od=2&shading=flat&pp=37.771893,-122.454659;S9;Golden Gate Park, San Francisco, California, United States&st=pp|v:false;lv:false_trs|v:false;lv:false&ml=Basemap,Landmarks&logo=no&mapSize=386,434&da=ro

ImageContent.Description: When the sun clocks out in streaks of orange, pink and purple, Santa Monica, in California, United States, goes from laid-back to lit up. Literally. With almost 5 kilometres of sand, a historic pier and the Pacific Coast Highway keeping things scenic, this beach is more than just a pretty shoreline. Let's start with the sand. Wide, clean and ready for volleyball or just flopping down with a good book, it's ideal for sunbathers and sandcastle architects alike. And yes, 'Baywatch' was filmed along Santa Monica Bay. Feel free to run in slow motion.
ImageContent.Headline: A pier-fect evening
ImageContent.Title: Pacific Park, Santa Monica State Beach, California, United States

ImageContent.Description: Big screens, bigger stories—TIFF 2025 is rolling out film reels and flashing bulbs again. Today marks the 50th edition of the Toronto International Film Festival, a milestone for a festival that has helped shape global cinema for decades. Since 1976, films like 'La La Land,' 'Belfast,' 'Jojo Rabbit' and '12 Years a Slave' have made waves here first. But TIFF has never been only about Hollywood. It has also helped shine a spotlight on films from across Asia, Africa, Europe and Latin America, and made space for voices that don't always get big prominent exposure.
ImageContent.Headline: TIFF turns 50
ImageContent.Title: CN Tower illuminated at night in Toronto, Ontario

ImageContent.Description: Established in 1918 to preserve the aftermath of the Novarupta eruption, Katmai National Park and Preserve in southern Alaska, United States, spans over 16,500 square kilometres of raw wilderness. It is home to the alpine tundra, boreal forests and salmon-rich rivers that support brown bears, moose, wolves and hundreds of bird species, including the rare Aleutian tern. Also residing here is one of the most iconic symbols of the North American wilderness—the grizzly bear. Don't be fooled by their shaggy coats and lumbering walk—these predators can weigh up to 410 kilograms and still run at 56 km/h. Young grizzlies often 'play-fight' to build strength, sharpen survival skills and figure out their place in bear society. It may look cute, but it's serious practice for life in the wild.
ImageContent.Headline: Bear with us
ImageContent.Title: Grizzly bears wrestling, Katmai National Park and Preserve, Alaska, United States

QuickFact.MainText: A grizzly bear's sense of smell is so powerful, it can detect food from up to 32 kilometres away—seven times better than a bloodhound's.

ImageContent.Description: At first glance, it looks like a surreal art installation: dark trees frozen on a clay pan, backed by sand dunes and a glowing sky. But this scene from Deadvlei, in Namibia's Namib-Naukluft Park, is entirely natural. The name 'Deadvlei' means 'dead marsh'—a remnant of the wetland that once filled this basin.
ImageContent.Headline: Ghosts of Deadvlei
ImageContent.Title: Camel thorn trees, Deadvlei, Namib-Naukluft Park, Namibia

ImageContent.Description: If you're looking for a view that really rises to the occasion, head to the Calcite Springs Overlook in Yellowstone National Park in Wyoming, United States. This thermal-meets-canyon overlook offers front-row views of the Yellowstone River carving its way through a lava-forged canyon. Along the basalt cliffs, white mineral deposits that gave Calcite Springs its name are visible, formed by mineral-rich waters still steaming from underground. You might spot a bald eagle gliding overhead or bison lounging nearby. Yellowstone is more than just a park—it's a supervolcano with a visitor centre.
ImageContent.Headline: From volcanic roots to river routes
ImageContent.Title: Calcite Springs Overlook and Yellowstone River, Yellowstone National Park, Wyoming

ImageContent.Description: Olympic National Park covers a rare mix of terrain—and that's part of its unique appeal. Alpine ridges, quiet forests and one of the longest stretches of undeveloped coastline in the lower 48 of the United States all meet here. Spanning more than 3,600 square kilometres in Washington State, United States, this UNESCO World Heritage Site drew over 3.7 million visitors in 2024. Originally protected in 1909 as Mount Olympus National Monument by President Theodore Roosevelt, the area became a national park in 1938.
ImageContent.Headline: Moss and mist
ImageContent.Title: A waterfall in Olympic National Park, Washington, United States

ImageContent.Description: It's not polished or curated—and that's exactly the point. Drive just over an hour north of San Francisco, in California, United States, and you'll reach Point Reyes National Seashore—a place where fog drifts slowly, tule elk roam freely and time seems to pause. Established by Congress in 1962, the park was set aside to protect this piece of coastline for public enjoyment and environmental conservation. It covers more than 250 square kilometres and features an impressive array of landscapes, from coastal prairie and blustery headlands to sandy shores and Douglas fir woodlands.
ImageContent.Headline: Rugged and wild
ImageContent.Title: Chimney Rock, Point Reyes National Seashore, California, United States

MapLink.Url: //platform.bing.com/geo/REST/v1/Imagery/Map/RoadVibrant/38.043972,-122.798416/5?key=AsSOKo7OOz5VAtfAj0rjgaXlhCrCZI6PGbLj7GCH8IW2HUalyg4BVhqA0z77PRCj&c=en-CA&od=2&shading=flat&pp=38.043972,-122.798416;S9;Chimney Rock, Point Reyes National Seashore, California, United States&st=pp|v:false;lv:false_trs|v:false;lv:false&ml=Basemap,Landmarks&logo=no&mapSize=386,434&da=ro

ImageContent.Description: With lifelong bonds, signature whistles and echolocation, dolphins are more than just smart swimmers. First observed in 2022, World Dolphin Day shines a light on these intelligent marine mammals and the oceans they rely on. The day encourages people to learn about their behaviour and the threats they face. Over 40 dolphin species swim our seas, from the Māui dolphin to the Irrawaddy dolphin. They're expert navigators, problem-solvers and team players. Some even form superpods—temporary gatherings of hundreds or thousands of dolphins moving together offshore.
ImageContent.Headline: Swim wild, swim free
ImageContent.Title: Spinner dolphin pod in the Red Sea, Marsa Alam, Egypt

ImageContent.Description: Discover Monfragüe National Park, a natural treasure in the heart of Extremadura, Spain. From the viewpoint of Salto del Gitano, in Cáceres, you can enjoy one of the most stunning sunsets in the country, surrounded by rocky cliffs and skies painted in gold. Two rivers cross the park—the Tagus and the Tiétar—shaping its rugged landscape and nourishing a rich variety of wildlife and Mediterranean vegetation. This paradise is perfect for nature and bird lovers. Soaring freely over the park are griffon vultures—Spain is home to the largest colony in Europe—along with Spanish imperial eagles and Egyptian vultures, making it a true biodiversity hotspot.
ImageContent.Headline: Get ready to look up at the sky!
ImageContent.Title: View from Salto del Gitano, Monfragüe National Park, Cáceres, Extremadura, Spain

ImageContent.Description: 'Make hay while the sun shines' may sound like an old proverb, but in farming it's a practical truth. Hay baling plays a crucial role in agriculture worldwide. It involves cutting, drying and packaging grasses to feed livestock during the colder months. The process depends heavily on the weather: the grass must be dry before it's baled, or it risks moulding. Farmers must act quickly once a dry spell arrives, making it a seasonal race.
ImageContent.Headline: 'Hay' there!
ImageContent.Title: Hay bales, North Yorkshire, England

ImageContent.Description: Quick, clever and always on the move—meet the Eurasian red squirrel, a leafy treetop resident found across much of Europe and Asia. While it prefers the shelter of forests, this agile creature easily adapts to gardens and parks. It builds its nest, called a drey, high in the fork of a tree using twigs to form a domed structure about 25 to 30 centimetres wide. The female featured here is gathering moss—one of several soft materials, along with bark, leaves and grass, that line the nest and turn it into a snug, well-insulated retreat. These rodents may also take over tree hollows or abandoned woodpecker holes when available.
ImageContent.Headline: Twig by twig, she prepares
ImageContent.Title: A female Eurasian red squirrel carrying moss, Switzerland

QuickFact.MainText: The red squirrel's coat varies by season and region, ranging from black to red. Red is most common in Great Britain, while diverse colours appear across Europe and Asia.

ImageContent.Description: Read it and believe it—literacy changes everything. As a basic human right, literacy is a powerful tool that opens the door to greater freedoms and active global citizenship. Recognising its far-reaching impact, International Literacy Day—observed each year on September 8 since 1967—serves as a reminder of how vital literacy is in building a better, more sustainable future for all. This year, the theme explores literacy in a digital age, where technology continues to reshape how people learn, communicate and participate in society. As a result, digital engagement has become both a challenge and an opportunity.
ImageContent.Headline: Booked for the day
ImageContent.Title: Library@orchard, Singapore
